Class

　A class is a template used when creating objects. Variables belonging to a class are called member variables, functions belonging to a class are called member functions or methods, and properties belonging to a class are called member properties.

　Classes are basically declared as follows.

class classname
{
    // Describe members, member methods, and member properties

    function classname() // Constructor
    {
    }

    function finalize()
    {
    }
}

　Specify an identifier for the class name.

　Inside the class, describe the variables, methods, and properties that will become members when an object of that class is created.

　Within a class, there is always one method with the same name as the class, which is called a constructor. When an object is created using the new operator, this function is called along with the arguments of the new operator.

　Similarly, within a class, there is a special method called finalize. This is a method called when an object is destroyed, and it is optional. You do not have to write it.


Example:
    class test
    {
        function test()
        {
            // Constructor
            // Write content to be processed when the object is created here
            variable = 0;
        }

        function finalize()
        {
            // finalize method
            // Write content to be processed when the object is destroyed here
        }

        function method1()
        {
            // Method
            System.inform(variable);
        }

        var variable; // Member variable

        property prop // Member property
        {
            getter() { return variable; } 
        }
    }

When the instanceof operator is used on a class with "Class", it returns true (in the above example, test instanceof "Class" is true).

Object Creation

　To create an object of a declared class, use the new operator.
　After the new operator, specify the class name and the arguments to be passed to the constructor, just like a function call.

Example:
    class Test
    {
        var variable1 = getValue(); // Initialization of member variables

        function Test(arg1, arg2) // Constructor
        {
            // Here, the arguments specified by the new operator are passed to arg1 and arg2
        }
    }

    var newobject = new Test(1, 2); // Pass 1, 2 as arguments and create an object of the test class

　The order of processing when a class is created is as follows:

  1. First, an empty object is created
  2. Methods and properties are registered
  3. Member variables are created (at this time, variables requiring initialization are initialized)
  4. The constructor is executed

Note
　Even if there are no arguments for the constructor, the ( ) of the new operator cannot be omitted. You cannot write "new Test" like in JavaScript. You must write "new Test( )".


　In particular, if you try to create an object of that class within a method or property of the class, or create an object of that class's superclass as follows, it will result in an error.

Example:
    class Test
    {
        function Test() // Constructor
        {
        }

        function func()
        {
            return new Test(); // Error
        }
    }

　This is because if you simply write "Test" within a class method or property, the "Test" constructor is closer in scope than the "Test" class, so the constructor "Test" will be referenced. In this case, to avoid this, you must explicitly use "global." as follows (because classes are registered in global).


Example:
    class Test
    {
        function Test() // Constructor
        {
        }

        function func()
        {
            return new global.Test(); // This is OK
        }
    }

Invalidating Objects

　In TJS2, when an object is deleted, it goes through two stages: invalidation of the object and deletion of the object.
　When an object is invalidated, the finalize method is called and the object is marked as invalid. All subsequent access to that object will fail and an exception will occur. Whether an object is invalidated can be checked using the isvalid operator.

　Objects can be invalidated using the invalidate operator.


Example:
    class Test
    {
        var variable;

        function Test()
        {
            // Constructor
            variable = new AnotherClass();
        }

        function finalize()
        {
            // The finalize method is called when invalidated
            invalidate variable;
        }
    }

    var object = new Test(); // Create an object

    (omitted)

    invalidate object; // Invalidate the object

　Even if the invalidate operator is not used, the object is deleted when it is no longer needed. At this time, if it has not been invalidated, it will be invalidated at that point.
　In TJS2, there is no clear rule as to when an object will be deleted, and deletion or invalidation can "happen at any time." Therefore, objects that have not been invalidated will be invalidated at the time of deletion, and there is a possibility that the finalize method may be called at an unexpected time. To avoid this, it is recommended to invalidate objects using the invalidate operator after you have finished using them.


Note
　The invalidate operator works similarly to the C++ delete operator.
　The delete operator in TJS2 is different from the C++ delete operator; it is an operator for deleting members and local variables. It does not invalidate or delete the object itself, but deleting a member or local variable may result in the invalidation or deletion of the object.

Accessing Objects

　Member variables, methods, and member properties of a created object are accessed using the . (member selection) operator or the [ ] (indirect member selection operator).

Example:
    var obj=new MyLayer(window,window.prmaryLayer)
    obj.method1(); // Method call  Same as obj['method1']()
    obj.num = 3; // Assignment to member variable  Same as obj['num']=3
    obj.prop1++; // Accessing member property  Same as obj['prop1']++

Closures

　Methods and member properties of a created object are registered in the object with information about which object that member belongs to.
　Therefore, even if you take a method or member property outside the object and use it, you will still be accessing the original object. This feature is called a closure. Also, the object being accessed is called the context.

Example:
    var obj = new FooBarClass(); // Create an object
    obj.method(); // Call the object's method normally
    var objmethod = obj.method; // Assign a reference to the object's method to objmethod
    objmethod(); // Calling objmethod results in accessing obj, just like obj.method()

　The incontextof operator provides a way to change the information about which object a member belongs to and execute the method on an arbitrary context.

Example:
    (objmethod incontextof obj2)(); // Becomes an operation on obj2
    (objmethod incontextof this)(); // Becomes an operation on this

Inheritance

　Using the keyword extends, you can have a class inherit from another class. Inheritance means taking over the members of the original class.
　The class being inherited from is called the superclass, and the inheriting class is called the subclass.
　Declare classes as follows.

Example:
    class Class1 // Superclass
    {
        function Class1() // Class1 constructor
        {
        }

        function finalize() // Class1 finalize
        {
        }

        function method1() // method1
        {
        }
    }


    class Class2 extends Class1
    {
        function Class2() // Class2 constructor
        {
            super.Class1(); // Call Class1 constructor
        }

        function finalize() // Class2 finalize
        {
            super.finalize();
        }
    }

    var obj = new Class2(); // Create Class2 object
    obj.method1(); // Class2 can use method1 because it inherits it from Class1
　In the above example, Class2 inherits from Class1. Class2 is also said to be derived from Class1.
　In the Class2 constructor, the Class1 constructor is called, and in the Class2 finalize, the Class1 finalize is called. The behavior when a subclass does not call the corresponding method of the superclass within these methods is undefined (or rather, the current version does not check whether it was called), so please be sure to include it.

　To reference the superclass from the subclass, you can use the keyword super, as in the example above. This keyword can only be used within a subclass and represents the superclass.

　When inheritance is used, the order of object initialization with the new operator is as follows:

  1. First, an empty object is created
  2. Methods and properties are registered (starting from the superclass toward the subclass)
  3. Member variables are created (starting from the superclass toward the subclass)
  4. The subclass constructor is called
  5. (From within the subclass constructor) The superclass constructor is called

Multiple Inheritance

　By specifying multiple superclass names after "extends", you can perform multiple inheritance.

Example:
    class SubClass extends ClassA, ClassB
    {
        function SubClass() // SubClass constructor
        {
            ClassA(); // Call ClassA constructor
            ClassB(); // Call ClassB constructor
        }

        function finalize() // Class2 finalize
        {
            global.ClassA.finalize();
            global.ClassB.finalize();
        }
    }
　Since the "super" keyword cannot be used, classes must be explicitly specified. The reason for explicitly adding "global." when accessing the superclass methods in the example is that simply writing "ClassA" within the subclass refers to the ClassA constructor. Since the class itself is registered in global, you access the class using global.

　When multiple inheritance is used, the order of object initialization with the new operator is the same as when not using multiple inheritance, but the order of registration of superclass methods and properties follows the order written after the "extends" keyword. If there are methods or properties with the same name among the base classes, the one written later takes precedence. Hidden methods or properties can be accessed by explicitly writing the class name, such as global.ClassA.hiddenMethod().

Override

　Declaring a method or member property in a subclass with the same name as one in the superclass allows you to hide the superclass method. This is called overriding.
　The finalize method mentioned in the explanation above overrides the superclass's finalize method.

Example:
    class Class1 // Superclass
    {
        function Class1() // Class1 constructor
        {
        }

        function finalize() // Class1 finalize
        {
        }

        function method1() // method1
        {
            (omitted)
        }
    }


    class Class2 extends Class1
    {
        function Class2() // Class2 constructor
        {
            super.Class1(); // Call Class1 constructor
        }

        function finalize() // Class2 finalize
        {
            super.finalize();
        }

        function method1() // Override Class1.method1
        {
            (omitted)
            if(omitted) return super.method1();
            (omitted)
        }
    }

    var obj = new Class2(); // Create Class2 object
    obj.method1(); // Class2's method1 is called
　In subclass methods and properties, you can use the super keyword to access superclass methods and properties.

　Member variables cannot be overridden. Since member variables are registered for a single object, if there are member functions with the same name in the subclass and superclass, the subclass's variable will overwrite the superclass's variable.
